items.title: Russia signs contract to build lunar power plant by 2036

featured_image.name: Bond villain Putin wants to build a nuclear power plant on the MOON in just 10 years to power space-conquering plot

items.description:
Russia's space agency has signed a contract to construct a power plant on the moon within the next decade, marking the latest development in an intensifying global race for lunar dominance between major powers.

Roscosmos, Russia's state space corporation, announced on December 24 that it signed a government contract with the Lavochkin Association aerospace company to complete work on building a lunar power plant by 2036[1][2]. The facility is intended to provide long-term energy for Russia's lunar program and the International Lunar Research Station, a joint project with China that has attracted more than a dozen participating countries[1][3].

While Roscosmos did not explicitly confirm the plant would be nuclear, the project includes participation from Rosatom, Russia's state nuclear corporation, and the Kurchatov Institute, the country's leading nuclear research facility[1][4]. The announcement follows a memorandum of understanding signed by Russia and China in May regarding cooperation on lunar power infrastructure[5][3].

items.title: Korean team unveils anode-free battery that doubles EV range

featured_image.name: Battery breakthrough lets EVs drive much farther than before

items.description:
A South Korean research team has achieved a volumetric energy density of 1,270 watt-hours per liter in an anode-free lithium metal battery, nearly double that of current lithium-ion batteries used in electric vehicles[1][2][3]. The development, published in Advanced Materials on December 23, could enable EVs to travel from Seoul to Busan and back on a single charge without increasing battery size[1][2].

The joint research team, led by Professor Soojin Park and Dr. Dong-Yeob Han of POSTECH's Department of Chemistry, together with Professor Nam-Soon Choi and Dr. Saehun Kim of KAIST, and Professor Tae Kyung Lee and researcher Junsu Son of Gyeongsang National University, eliminated the conventional graphite anode altogether[1][2][3]. Instead, lithium ions stored in the cathode deposit directly onto a copper current collector during charging, freeing up space for energy storage[1][2].

items.title: Copper prices hit record high near $12,300 per ton

featured_image.name: Copper Hits Fresh All-Time High After Fed Delivers Rate Cut

items.description:
Copper prices surged to unprecedented levels this week, reaching $12,282 per ton on Wednesday and marking the industrial metal's strongest annual performance since the global financial crisis[1]. The rally has pushed prices up approximately 40% for the year, driven by a confluence of supply disruptions, anticipated U.S. tariffs, and surging demand from artificial intelligence infrastructure[2][1].

Three-month copper on the London Metal Exchange touched an all-time high of $12,159.50 per ton, before settling around $12,243 on Wednesday[3][4]. The surge comes as investors pile into the metal amid expectations that a rush of copper into the United States—aimed at front-running potential import tariffs—will leave buyers elsewhere in a tight spot[2][1].

items.title: US, Russia announce rival lunar nuclear power plans

featured_image.name: NASA wants to put a nuclear reactor on the Moon by 2030

items.description:
The United States and Russia unveiled competing strategies for nuclear power on the moon within days of each other, marking a new chapter in the increasingly contested race for lunar dominance.

President Donald Trump signed an executive order on December 18 directing NASA to deploy a nuclear reactor on the lunar surface by 2030, while Russian space agency Roscosmos announced December 23 it had contracted to build a lunar power plant by 2036[1][2][3]. The near-simultaneous announcements underscore how space exploration has evolved from scientific cooperation to strategic competition between major powers.

items.title: China vows countermeasures to planned US chip tariffs

featured_image.name: US Holds Off on New Chinese Chip Tariffs Amid Trump-Xi Truce

items.description:
China warned Wednesday it will take countermeasures if the United States proceeds with planned tariffs on Chinese semiconductor imports, escalating tensions just a day after Washington announced it would delay imposing the duties until mid-2027[1][2][3].

Lin Jian, a foreign ministry spokesperson, said at a regular press briefing that China "firmly opposes" the U.S. "indiscriminate use of tariffs" and "unreasonable suppression" of Chinese industries[4][1][2]. He urged Washington to "correct its wrong practices" and said Beijing would take measures to safeguard its "legitimate rights and interests" if the U.S. persists in its actions[4][2].

The Chinese response came after the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative concluded Tuesday that China's drive for dominance in the semiconductor sector is "unreasonable" and burdens U.S. commerce[5][6]. However, the agency said it would maintain a zero percent tariff rate on Chinese chip imports for the next 18 months before increasing duties on June 23, 2027, to a rate that will be announced at least 30 days in advance[5][7][8].

items.title: UConn engineers create lensless camera with microscope-level resolution

featured_image.name: Lensless On-Chip Microscopy Platform Shows Slides in Full ...

items.description:
University of Connecticut engineers have developed a computational imaging system that achieves ultra-high resolution without traditional lenses, a breakthrough that could transform fields from forensic science to medical diagnostics. The technology, published in Nature Communications last month, eliminates decades-old constraints that have limited optical imaging[1][2][3].

The Multiscale Aperture Synthesis Imager (MASI) resolves features as small as 780 nanometers from two centimeters away—a combination previously impossible with conventional optical systems[1][3]. According to UConn Today, traditional microscopes typically require working distances of less than one millimeter to achieve comparable resolution[2].

items.title: BP sells 65% of Castrol to Stonepeak for $6B

featured_image.name: Devil's in the details: Why BP's debt may deter a buyer | Reuters

items.description:
BP agreed to sell a 65 percent stake in its Castrol lubricants business to investment firm Stonepeak in a deal valuing the unit at $10.1 billion, the company announced on December 24, marking one of the oil giant's largest asset sales as it seeks to reduce debt and refocus on core operations[1][2][3].

The British energy company will receive approximately $6 billion in proceeds from the transaction, which includes about $800 million for the prepayment of future dividend income on its retained 35 percent stake[2]. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board will invest up to $1.05 billion alongside Stonepeak, resulting in an indirect stake in the 126-year-old lubricants business[1][4][5].

"Today's announcement is a very good outcome for all stakeholders," said Carol Howle, interim CEO at BP, in a statement[2]. "The transaction allows us to realise value for our shareholders, generating significant proceeds while continuing to benefit from Castrol's strong growth momentum."

items.title: Researchers propose satellites as AI nodes for 6G networks

featured_image.name: Edge computing gives wings to low-Earth-orbit satellite ...

items.description:
Researchers from the University of Hong Kong and Xidian University have introduced a framework to transform satellites into dual-function communication centers and computing servers for the next generation of mobile networks. The approach, called space-ground fluid AI, aims to deliver artificial intelligence services globally as the race toward sixth-generation networks accelerates ahead of expected commercialization in 2030[1][2].

The research, published in the journal Engineering on December 22, addresses a fundamental challenge in extending AI capabilities beyond terrestrial networks[1][2]. According to the International Telecommunication Union, 6G will introduce new usage scenarios including "integrated artificial intelligence and communication" and "ubiquitous connectivity"[1][2]. However, ensuring continuous AI services in remote and underserved areas remains difficult with ground-based infrastructure alone.

The space-ground fluid AI framework draws its name from water's ability to flow seamlessly across boundaries. AI model parameters and data features move continuously between satellites and ground stations, adapting to the ever-changing network topology created by satellite mobility[2][3]. Professor Kaibin Huang, a key researcher on the project, noted the framework leverages satellites' predictable trajectories to enable fluid horizontal and vertical task migration across networks[4][3].

items.title: MIT develops single-pull string method for instant 3D deployable structures

featured_image.name: Single string pull enables rapid assembly of futuristic 3D ...

items.description:
Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have developed a technique that transforms flat panels into complex three-dimensional structures with a single pull of a string, potentially enabling rapid deployment of emergency shelters, medical facilities, and space habitats.

The method, presented December 17 at the Association for Computing Machinery's SIGGRAPH Asia 2025 conference in Hong Kong and announced by MIT on December 22, converts user-designed 3D structures into interconnected flat tiles that deploy smoothly with minimal friction[1][2][3]. When the string is released, the structure returns to its compact, flat configuration, allowing for repeated use without damage or reassembly[1][4][5].

"The simplicity of the whole actuation mechanism is a real benefit of our approach," said Akib Zaman, an electrical engineering and computer science graduate student at MIT and lead author of the research paper[1][5]. "The user just needs to provide their intended design, and then our method optimizes it in such a way that it holds the shape after just one pull on the string."

items.title: Japan's H3 rocket fails to deliver satellite to orbit

featured_image.name: H3 Launch Failure Leaves Japan Without Core Rockets, Deals Blow to Global Competitiveness in Space Development

items.description:
Two rocket failures within hours of each other dealt significant blows to Asian space ambitions this week, as Japan's flagship H3 rocket failed to deliver a navigation satellite into orbit and South Korean startup Innospace's commercial vehicle crashed shortly after liftoff in Brazil.

Japan's H3 rocket launched at 10:51 a.m. local time Monday from the Tanegashima Space Center carrying the Michibiki 5 navigation satellite, but the second-stage engine shut down prematurely during its second ignition, according to the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency[1][2][3][4]. The rocket's first stage performed normally, but telemetry data showed hydrogen tank pressure in the second stage began dropping during the first stage burn, JAXA executive Masashi Okada told reporters[1][2]. Whether the satellite separated from the rocket or where it ended up remains unknown[1][2].

Hours later, South Korean company Innospace's Hanbit-Nano rocket lifted off from Brazil's Alcantara Space Center at 10:13 p.m. local time but crashed approximately 30 seconds after liftoff[3][5][6][7]. The vehicle initially followed its planned vertical trajectory before an anomaly caused it to fall to the ground within a pre-designated safety zone, with no reported casualties[5][7][8]. The rocket was carrying eight payloads, including five satellites for undisclosed customers from Brazil and India[3][5][9].

items.title: US blockade forces Venezuela to store crude oil on anchored tankers

featured_image.name: US seizes sanctioned oil tanker off coast of Venezuela, Trump says

items.description:
Venezuela's state oil company PDVSA has begun storing crude oil and fuel on tankers anchored in its waters as onshore storage tanks reach capacity, following U.S. Coast Guard seizures of vessels carrying Venezuelan oil and President Donald Trump's blockade declaration earlier this month.

PDVSA started transferring oil inventories to tankers over the weekend, according to company documents and shipping data reviewed by Reuters[1][2][3]. The move comes after the U.S. intercepted the Skipper and Centuries tankers in the Caribbean Sea, both fully loaded with Venezuelan crude, and pursued a third empty vessel approaching Venezuela's coast[1][3][4].

More than a dozen oil cargoes remain stuck in Venezuelan waters as ship owners hesitate to depart following Trump's announcement of a "total and complete blockade" of all sanctioned vessels[3][4][5]. The emerging backlog is rapidly filling PDVSA's onshore tanks at the Jose terminal, which receives extra heavy oil from the Orinoco Belt, Venezuela's main production region[1][3][4].

items.title: US deploys 15,000 troops, carrier near Venezuela

featured_image.name: US aircraft carrier moves into Latin America region, escalating Venezuela tensions

items.description:
The United States has positioned one of its largest military buildups in the Caribbean in decades, deploying advanced fighter jets, warships, and thousands of troops as President Donald Trump escalates a confrontation with Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro through naval blockades and oil tanker seizures.

As of December 23, approximately 12,000 to 15,000 US military personnel are operating in the region under Operation Southern Spear[1][2][3], with forces positioned to conduct potential strikes into Venezuelan territory. The deployment includes the USS Gerald R. Ford[1][4]—the world's largest aircraft carrier—along with a strike group of destroyers equipped with Tomahawk land-attack missiles[1][4][2].
